Literature Review: Biologging and biotelemetry have revolutionized our understanding of marine animal ecology, physiology, and behavior, providing unprecedented insights into the secret lives of creatures inhabiting the vast and often inaccessible ocean environments. These technologies have evolved significantly over the past few decades, enabling researchers to collect a wealth of data on marine animals' movements, physiology, and interactions with their environment.The history of marine animal tracking dates back to the 1960s when simple radio tags were first used to monitor fish movements (Block et al., 2011). Since then, the field has experienced rapid technological advancements, with the development of increasingly sophisticated and miniaturized sensors. Modern biologging devices can now record a wide array of parameters, including location, depth, temperature, acceleration, and even heart rate, providing a comprehensive picture of an animal's life in its natural habitat (Hussey et al., 2015).One of the primary applications of biologging and biotelemetry in marine research has been in the field of movement ecology. These technologies have allowed scientists to track the long-distance migrations of various species, from sea turtles to great white sharks, revealing previously unknown migration routes and important habitat areas (Hays et al., 2016). For instance, Block et al. (2011) used electronic tags to track the movements of Atlantic bluefin tuna, uncovering their trans-ocean basin migrations and identifying critical feeding and breeding grounds. Such information is crucial for developing effective conservation strategies and marine protected areas.In addition to tracking movements, biologging devices have provided valuable insights into the physiological adaptations of marine animals. For example, Ponganis et al. (2011) used heart rate recorders and accelerometers to study the diving physiology of emperor penguins, revealing how these birds manage their oxygen stores during deep dives. Similarly, Goldbogen et al. (2013) employed multi-sensor tags to investigate the feeding behavior and energetics of blue whales, demonstrating how these massive animals optimize their foraging strategies in relation to their prey density and distribution.Biologging has also shed light on predator-prey interactions in marine ecosystems. By combining animal-borne cameras with other sensors, researchers have been able to observe hunting behaviors and feeding events in species ranging from seals to sharks (Watanabe and Takahashi, 2013). These studies have not only improved our understanding of marine food webs but have also revealed how changing environmental conditions may impact predator-prey dynamics.Social interactions among marine animals have been another area of focus for biologging research. For instance, Krause et al. (2013) used proximity loggers to study the social networks of blacktip reef sharks, revealing complex and dynamic social structures within shark populations. Such studies provide valuable insights into the social behavior of marine species, which can have important implications for their conservation and management.Biologging and biotelemetry have also proven invaluable in assessing the impacts of anthropogenic stressors on marine animals. For example, DeRuiter et al. (2013) used digital acoustic recording tags to study the responses of Cuvier's beaked whales to naval sonar, providing critical information for mitigating the effects of human-generated noise on marine mammals. Similarly, biologging devices have been used to investigate the impacts of climate change on marine species, such as changes in distribution patterns and phenology (Hazen et al., 2013).As biologging technologies continue to advance, new opportunities for research are emerging. The integration of multiple sensors and the miniaturization of devices are enabling the collection of increasingly detailed and diverse data sets. For instance, the development of animal-borne environmental sample processors allows for the collection of genetic material from the surrounding water, providing information on the presence of prey species or environmental DNA (Scholin et al., 2009).The future of biologging and biotelemetry research lies in the analysis and integration of the vast amounts of data being generated. Big data approaches and international collaborations, such as the Ocean Tracking Network and the Global Tagging of Pelagic Predators project, are facilitating the sharing and analysis of data on a global scale (Hussey et al., 2015). These efforts are crucial for addressing large-scale environmental issues, such as the impacts of climate change on marine ecosystems.In conclusion, biologging and biotelemetry have become indispensable tools in marine research, providing unprecedented insights into the lives and environments of marine animals. As these technologies continue to evolve and data analysis techniques improve, they will undoubtedly play an increasingly important role in our understanding and conservation of marine ecosystems. The curiosity about the secret lives of marine animals, coupled with the urgent need to address global environmental challenges, will continue to drive innovation and research in this exciting field.
